page.title: 16LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: An interview with Mr Harold Holmes, the oldest ex-pupil of Glasshouses reveals that, if there was a whooping cough epidemic the school would be closed and the afflicted children would be expected to go to the gas works to breathe in the gas/lime mixture. In the 1930s Mrs Herena Lonsdale and Mrs Margaret Marton remember a fish and chip shop, two cobblers and two sweet shops in the village, whilst Mrs Barbara Johnson's memories of the 1950s and 1960s are of a village of workers' cottages surrounded by fields,of the last passenger train and the last goods' train going through ln 1951 and 1965 repectively, of school dinners being 2 shillings per week, and an annual school trip to the seaside or the Liverpool Docks.
